name: ING
mission: Intercultural Networks Group (ING) 3031 Tisch Way 110 Plaza West San Jose, CA 95128
theoryOfChange: ING (Islamic Networks Group) publishes 'ING Impact Reports' which provide comprehensive qualitative analyses of the meaningful change achieved through their initiatives and the fulfillment of their mission. They leverage tools such as before-and-after surveys, requester evaluations across multiple dimensions, storytelling, and testimonials to showcase the tangible ways their efforts drive sustainable, positive transformation. Their impact evaluations consistently report 85% or higher in improved perceptions, the relevance of ING content to professionals, and the usefulness of the content for their interactions with marginalized communities.

evaluationSources: Accredited Charity (Better Business Bureau Wise Giving Alliance (BBB-WGA))
COVID-19 Emergency Response Fund Inclusion (The San Francisco Foundation)

zakatClaimEvidence: The search results for 'ING' (referring to either The Ing Foundation or Islamic Networks Group) do not explicitly mention that the US organization accepts zakat donations, have dedicated zakat funds, or campaigns. While Islamic Networks Group (ING) is an Islamic organization, the provided information indicates they receive support from foundations involved in Muslim philanthropy, but not that ING itself directly accepts zakat. (Source: https://ing.org/donate/)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a program expense ratio of 39.5% and a fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
Total revenue for the period was $622,869.
The organization focuses on fostering a nuanced understanding of Muslims through monthly events.
ING tracks effectiveness through educator ratings and live audience attendance.
The organization's curriculum is utilized across multiple states and includes interfaith panels.
The organization engages participants through face-to-face presentations and digital outreach.
Donations can be made as general charitable giving (Sadaqah).
The organization provides engagement opportunities through its youth programs and volunteer initiatives.

The organization operates the Islamic Speakers Bureau and provides specialized Inclusion and Belonging Training to diverse audiences [2][5].

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a highly efficient fundraising model, reporting <cite id="1">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>.
ING's educational materials have achieved national penetration, with their <cite id="5">curriculum used in 50 states</cite>.
The organization reports strong feedback from its primary audience, achieving <cite id="3">96% educator satisfaction with content relevance</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: Islamic Networks Group has established a strong footprint in the religious and cultural education space since its founding in <cite id="7">1993</cite>. The organization's primary strength lies in its programmatic reach and content quality. By providing resources that achieve an <cite id="4">89% educator effectiveness rating</cite>, ING ensures that its interfaith panels and educational materials are well-received by target audiences. Furthermore, the charity operates with remarkable fundraising efficiency, spending <cite id="1">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, which indicates that public contributions are not being consumed by excessive fundraising campaigns.
rich_narrative.summary: Islamic Networks Inc, also known as Islamic Networks Group (ING), is a non-profit organization founded in <cite id="7">1993</cite> that is dedicated to promoting peace and cross-cultural understanding through educational outreach. The organization operates the Islamic Speakers Bureau and provides specialized Inclusion and Belonging Training to diverse audiences across the United States. In 2023, the organization reported a <cite id="2">Total Revenue of $622,869</cite>. While ING maintains an exceptional <cite id="1">Fundraising Efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, its financial model shows a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 39.5%</cite>, which falls significantly below industry standards. Despite this, the organization demonstrates strong educational reach, with its <cite id="5">curriculum used in 50 states</cite> and high reported impact metrics, including a <cite id="3">96% educator satisfaction with content relevance</cite> and an <cite id="4">89% educator effectiveness rating</cite>.
